author: AAP
title: SA to push Pyne for car, medical spending
text:
South Australia will use Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's sweeping cabinet changes to push for previously promised car industry funding and a new cancer treatment and research centre.
Opposition Leader Steven Marshall has also embraced the cabinet reshuffle, inviting Mr Turnbull, and each of his ministers to visit the state.
Premier Jay Weatherill called on Industry Minister Christopher Pyne to release car industry funds, promised by the federal coalition, to help component suppliers diversify and find new markets as Holden prepares to close its assembly plant in 2017.
"That could really smooth what is going to be a challenging transition for the car industry," he told ABC radio on Monday.
Mr Weatherill also said he would seek support for a proposed proton therapy centre in Adelaide, in line with the prime minister's technology-driven vison for Australia's future.
The premier last month called on the federal government to help fund the centre for advanced cancer patients who are currently forced to travel overseas for treatment.
Mr Marshall said he would seek to discuss opportunities for job creation in SA with Mr Turnbull and his ministers.
"It is important that we continue to have an open dialogue with the federal government so that we can advocate strongly on our state's behalf," he said.
In his first comments on the reshuffle, new Minister for Cities and the Built Environment Jamie Briggs was sentimental about the dumping of the former treasurer, describing Joe Hockey as "instrumental to me and my career".
"Joe is one of the finest, most caring and loyal people you could ever hope to know," Mr Briggs said.
